DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 253, 516]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 527, 758, 558]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[266, 874, 730, 890]]<|/det|> This document consists of 9 printed pages and 3 blank pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 823, 107]]<|/det|>
The aim of this experiment is to determine the internal volume of a test-tube using displacement methods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 880, 153]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions referring to Figs. 1.1, 1.2 and 1.3. You are supplied with a beaker of water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 180, 479, 387]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 180, 479, 387]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.2

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 170, 831, 387]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 437, 146, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 437, 180, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 437, 875, 470]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(80 \text{cm}^3\) of water from the beaker into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume \(V_1\) of water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 481, 870, 500]]<|/det|>
\[V_{1} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 513, 181, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 513, 875, 562]]<|/det|>
Lower the test-tube, closed end first, into the water in the measuring cylinder and push it down until it is filled with water, as shown in Fig. 1.2. Record the new water level \(V_2\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 575, 870, 593]]<|/det|>
\[V_{2} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 606, 183, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 606, 875, 641]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{G}}\) of the glass of the test-tube using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{G}} = (V_{2} - V_{1})\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 653, 870, 670]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{G}} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 668, 875, 686]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 699, 148, 717]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 699, 875, 732]]<|/det|>
Remove the test-tube from the measuring cylinder and pour the water from the tube and the measuring cylinder into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 745, 183, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 745, 875, 777]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(70 \text{cm}^3\) of water from the beaker into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume \(V_3\) of water.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 790, 870, 808]]<|/det|>
\[V_{3} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 822, 181, 840]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 822, 875, 870]]<|/det|>
Gently put the test-tube, open end first, into the water in the measuring cylinder and carefully push it down with your finger or pencil until it is just covered with water, as shown in Fig. 1.3. Record the new water level \(V_4\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 883, 870, 901]]<|/det|>
\[V_{4} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 577, 92]]<|/det|>
Calculate the increase in water level \((V_{4} - V_{3})\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 149, 870, 170]]<|/det|>
\[(V_{4} - V_{3}) = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad (3)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 182, 180, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 182, 875, 201]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of air in the test-tube using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = (V_{4} - V_{3}) - V_{\mathrm{G}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 257, 870, 276]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{A}} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad (3)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 275, 875, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 146, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 305, 873, 370]]<|/det|>
Remove the test-tube from the measuring cylinder and pour the water from the measuring cylinder into the beaker. Fill the test-tube to the top with water from the beaker. Pour the water from the test-tube into the measuring cylinder. Record the volume \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) of water from the tube.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[540, 382, 870, 402]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{W}} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad (1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 146, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 428, 873, 477]]<|/det|>
The aim of this experiment is to determine the internal volume of the test-tube by two methods. The two values are \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) (obtained from parts **(a)** and **(b)**) and \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) (obtained from part **(c)**). The values obtained from your readings may not be the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 490, 873, 539]]<|/det|>
Assuming that the experiments have been carried out correctly and carefully, and that the measuring cylinder scale is accurate, suggest two reasons why the value \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) may be inaccurate and two reasons why the value \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) may be inaccurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 553, 188, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>V<sub>A</sub>:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 585, 870, 602]]<|/det|>
reason 1 ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 647, 870, 663]]<|/det|>
reason 2 ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 707, 193, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>V<sub>W</sub>:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 739, 870, 755]]<|/det|>
reason 1 ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 800, 870, 816]]<|/det|>
reason 2 ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 847, 875, 865]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 718, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the heating of a thermometer bulb. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 650, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 2.1 and 2.2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[257, 129, 692, 265]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 304, 875, 351]]<|/det|> 
You are provided with a lamp and a rule. Do not move the lamp or the rule. During the experiment, you will read temperature values from the thermometer. You should use the card provided to shield your eyes from the direct rays of the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 364, 148, 382]]<|/det|>

\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .................................................... [1]

Record in Table 2.1 the distance \(d\) between the thermometer bulb and the surface of the lamp. Also record the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer.

Place the thermometer so that its bulb is a vertical distance \(d_{\mathrm{V}} = 100 \mathrm{mm}\) from the top surface of the lamp, as shown in Fig. 2.2. Use the \(100 \mathrm{mm}\) rod provided to obtain the correct distance. Record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{V}}\) shown on the thermometer.

A student suggests that \(\theta_{\mathrm{V}}\) will be higher than the thermometer reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) because thermal energy will travel by infra-red radiation and convection to the thermometer bulb above the lamp but by infra-red radiation only when the bulb is to one side of the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 635, 91]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a lens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 570, 122]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 135, 755, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 297, 510, 314]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 329, 148, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 329, 735, 346]]<|/det|>
Place the screen at a distance \(d = 0.800 \text{m}\) from the illuminated object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 360, 148, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 359, 873, 406]]<|/det|>
Place the lens between the object and the screen and close to the object. Move the lens towards the screen until an enlarged image is formed on the screen. Adjust the position of the lens until the image is as clearly focused as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 421, 148, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 421, 830, 438]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 875, 508]]<|/det|>
Briefly describe a precaution that you took in this experiment in order to obtain a reliable result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[789, 613, 876, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]
